segments.text: enough light that you could read the lettering on my white phosphorus rockets.
I don't know if you know about white phosphorus, but it burns without, I mean, you can put it in water.
It can even burn to taste the oxygen in the water.
They're used for marking rounds.
You weren't supposed to engage the enemy with it.
And you could also see my fuel vent dripping fuel right by this burning canister.
And so I told the Air Force Stinger gunship,
that I picked up one of his flares on my wing and I was going to go back to the LZ.
And it was about a 15 minute flight back to the LZ.
So I turned left.
I could only do left hand turns.
Turn left, head back to the LZ, and called and told him to get out the crash truck.
And all this time I'd forgotten about the Vietnamese in the backseat.
He was the littlest one we had, little tiny guy.
And I looked over my shoulder to see how he was doing, and I said, pretty exciting, huh?
This guy had not undone the metal clamp holding the fire extinguisher.
He had ripped it out.
Found out later he had actually ripped this metal clamp out.
Had this little baby fire extinguisher, and he was holding it as if he could spray out the window of this fire, which he couldn't.
And you've heard the expression, people shaking like a leaf.
This man's entire body was violently shaking.
I've never seen anybody more scared in my life.
So I figured he wasn't going to be much help.
And I went back to the LZ, and the LZ, the landing strip, is built up on the edge of a 200-foot cliff.
And as I was heading on final into the wind, I started to lose altitude, and I had full power in.
And I'm losing altitude, and my rate of descent is taking me into the face of the cliff.
And that's, of course, not acceptable.
So I thought I would, if I had to, I would turn off to the left into the ocean.
Because if I turn to the right, I'm hitting another cliff.

Which meant I had to land at night, going away from shore, on the water's surface, with no flotation equipment, wearing steel-soled and towed combat boots, a pistol, a canteen, a survival vest, two bandoliers of ammunition.
Not only do I not have any flotation gear, but I'm responsible for the guy in the back seat.
So I thought I would do that as a last resort.
I'd see if I could clear the edge of the cliff.

And for some reason, and I don't know how, I got a little bit of a boost at the end, and I just barely cleared some tangle foot barbed wire at the edge of the cliff, and a bunker, and a road, and I landed on the overrun of the runway.
And so the next day, my crew chiefs gave me a party.
I got a plaque at home that had a little piece of the player sheet on it that they gave me.
I bet that guy didn't fly with you anymore.
Oh, yeah.
But he was scared.
We had another guy take a few rounds one day, and he took one round that shattered a pulley for his rudder controls and went through the rudder, the metal rudder itself, and lodged it in his boot.
It didn't hit him, but it stuck in his boot.
And the next day, he was due to go out on a mission.
We had so many missions we needed to get additional pilots in, so he'd come from another platoon.
And he was late getting out of the aircraft, and we went into the hangar to find him.
He was in the alert shack, lying on a cot, turning blue, having a convulsion.
He was so scared.
And so he was relieved we sent him back.
And I can understand, you know.
Bobby Beale flew the next day after he got shot down.
Bobby Beale was the guy that crashed and played in the bicycle with me and almost had the mid-air in the bicycle.
And then our last day in process, or out processing, we were flying from Quignon back to Camron.
We stopped at the train for lunch.
Again, he's flying in the front seat and I'm sitting in the back and he almost hit a C-130.
Bobby almost killed me three times.
But he's a big guy.
Do you feel that the communication was effective enough and also honest from the United States government to everyone in Vietnam?
Do you feel that they were hiding some information from you?
Oh, I think they were.
I think Johnson did, and I think Nixon did.
I flew for, I can't remember how long, two, three weeks.
where I couldn't fire, even have fired upon without calling for clearance.
And clearance came through Vietnamese sources.
And nobody ever told us why.
It was a stupid rule.
It was stupid.
If you're getting shot at and you can't shoot back, we shot back.
You know, we called for clearance, but we'd go ahead and shoot.
If they came back and said, you have clearance, we'd say, thank you.
If they came back and said, you don't have clearance, we'd say, thank you.
We'd already fired anyway.

One incident which made me hate the Vietnamese all the more, when I worked with the first of the 50th Mechanized, I'd do what is called recon by fire, and they were going to sweep an area, and they're in tanks, I mean, you're not going to surprise anybody.
What we wanted to do was break up ambushes and mines.
So I'd fire artillery into the bush ahead of them and set off secondary explosions where the mines were.
Shut off the...
Anyway, they were sweeping an area that had not been swept in a long time.
It was surrounded by open country, but it was a couple mile long, mile wide, real thick area.
And somebody decided they needed to sweep it.
So I called for the usual clearance to recon by fire with artillery ahead of them.
And the request was denied.
from sector, and sector was the Vietnamese control of the province.
I thought that was sort of unusual, but they normally ask for me when they do these sweeps.
So I flew over them for four hours.
Four hours was the limit of my fuel.
And this area was so thick that they had to dismount from the tanks and go by foot.
So I was relieved on station by another aircraft and went back to refuel
And while I was on the ground refueling, the word came that they'd been hit by a bunch of mines.
They started walking into mines, and they had about 20 guys injured from mines.
I don't think anybody died, but they were torn up pretty bad.
So they sent helicopters out to pick up the wounded and brought them back, and the little clinic was right behind my hangar.
and they unloaded the dust-offs right there outside of my hangar.
I had to help carry the wounded in.
And I'm convinced that somebody at sector knew that place was mine, and that's why I didn't get clearance to fire.
Also, have you seen the original movie, M.A.S.H.?
Not the movie, no.
Okay, well, whoever did the makeup for the casualties in that movie has been there.
Because these guys are dirty and they're burned.
And once you see somebody that's been hit by a mine or stepped on a mine, you don't forget it.
What do you think or what was one of the biggest mistakes you think we made?
We made giving them sanctuary.
imposing artificial rules.
When we first started bombing the North, the Joint Chiefs gave Johnson a list of 500 targets that they said should be hit within the first two weeks, no later than the first six weeks.
Johnson and his policy of gradual escalation, some of those targets never got hit.
Most of them didn't get hit for years.
He picked targets that were ineffectual, that had no military significance.
They blew up bushes again.
We could, in other words, at the time we flew in the north, not me, but U.S. pilots, they could not shoot the enemy planes on the ground.
They had to be in the air before we could shoot them down or blow up the planes.
Now, is that stupid or what?
You know, we couldn't put ground troops in the north.
Here you're fighting an enemy that's got ground troops in your area that you can't go into theirs, excuse me.
Just absolutely inane, insane, idiotic policies.
And we could have done a much better job.
Who was primarily responsible?
Was that Johnson saying?
Johnson refused to even have audience with Wheeler and other people from the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
He totally ignored their advice.
Totally ignored their advice.
Was that because he didn't really want to call it a war to the United States?
I don't know why it was.
I'm not inside the man's mind.
Rumor control has it that through hidden assets, he had holdings in Bell Helicopter and Sealand Transportation.
And Sealand Transportation may not mean anything to you, but if you saw the container ships coming in, Sealand...
made a ton of money on this war.

So if in fact, and this is only speculation, but if in fact he had financial interest in these companies and was therefore prolonging the war, well, if you believe what goes around comes around, he's getting what comes around now.
What did you think that the Kennedy administration did as far as engaging us in it?
Well, they were idealistic.
They were not real practical.
Eisenhower tried to keep us out of Vietnam.
He advised us against going into Vietnam and refused to get us involved when he was in office.
Kennedy, feeling that we could take on the world, got us involved with advisors, started the buildup.
Johnson completed the buildup.
Johnson thought he could have a war to boost the economy.
and have a war on poverty at the same time.
And he was mistaken.
He was mistaken in many things that he did.
His history also shows, in my opinion, that he was not what you call an honest politician, and therefore I put nothing past the man.
If you read the book Thud Ridge, it talks about the flights in the north to real Iowa.
But I fault Johnson for a lot of this.
Like I said, by the time Nixon got there, all he could do was try and get us out the best way possible.
Communists understand power.
Who was it?
Was it Lenin or Ho Chi Minh?
I think it was Lenin who said, political power comes from the barrel of a gun.
They understand power.
Whenever we bombed the North, they came to the negotiating table.
When we stopped,
They'd stop.
It was the bombing that got them to sign that stupid truce that they signed.
False though it was.
When Eisenhower took office from Truman, the war in Korea had been going on for a while and they'd been negotiating and fighting back and forth.
My father was on a ship offshore Korea.
It was a communications center for communications to our negotiators at Panmunjom.

Eisenhower had been in office a very short time, and he sent a message through that communications center that my father saw 200 negotiators saying, tell these people that unless they sign a peace, that we'll have a war like World War II.
And they signed it like that.
Now, that's what they understand, and we could have kicked them from here to China had we been allowed to.
And even when we didn't give
The sanctuary in North Vietnam, we gave them sanctuary in China.
They fly their planes.
The North Koreans flew their planes into China.
The Vietnamese flew theirs into China to protect them, just like the Iraqis flew theirs into Iran.
We always give our enemies sanctuary somewhere.
So this war was, I don't know if this is correct, it was different in a sense that our administration was wishy-washy.
Very much so.
Would not say go in and just get the enemy.
What sanctuaries did we give the Axis powers in World War II?
None.
We started giving sanctuary in Korea because we were afraid of widening the war.
The popular saying is you can't win a land war in Asia.
Well, we don't fight land wars anymore.
We fight combined arms wars.
Right.
And we did them so much damage, and we lost Ted for 68 in the press.
We won it militarily, and that's a fact.
And I challenge anyone to dispute that.
But yeah, we could have won that battle.
It was just stupidly, stupidly fine.
And that's the one thing, you know, would I want my sons to fight in a wasteful war like that?
Well, no, I wouldn't.
Would I advise them to go if
if they're called upon.
Yes, I would.
There are times that you stand on principle.
The people who went to Canada, I don't believe stood on principle.
They could have done alternative service.
I think they were basically cowards.
I heard people say, you know, I'm not going to go to Vietnam and get killed.
Well, first of all, not everybody went to Vietnam.
Second of all, very relatively few who went to Vietnam got killed.
That was a 10-year war.
We had 50,000 killed in 10 years.
That's 50,000 too many.
One is too many.
I believe that.
I also realize that we kill 50,000 a year on the highways.
So we've got to put it in perspective.
There were times when we were losing a lot.
The Life Magazine story, have you seen that?
Look in the library for the Life Magazine issue that takes a week's casualties.
People killed in a specific week.
They put in their name and their picture.
Now that'll get you.
That'll get you.
And yeah, it was a waste, but
And I think the thing to do is to fight.
Communism is not dead.
One of the people that's supporting Mandela in South Africa is a communist.
Some of the people trying to take over in Russia are communists.
Communism is not dead.
It is evil.
Everybody jokes at Reagan for calling it the evil empire.
It is the evil empire.
They lie, cheat, steal, and kill as a matter of policy.
Our government has screwed up, but theirs does it all the time as a matter of policy.
And we have got to continue to fight that.
So the idea then, you think...
was absolutely justified.
It's just the means, the way the war was fought.
The way it was fought.
See, Kennedy got a little involved, too, in the politics.
He got involved in changing the people in power in Vietnam.
The domino theory was, in fact, a valid theory, whether it worked out in practice or not.
There are some people who tell you that it did or it didn't.
Definitely, had we not fought them as much as we did, I think it probably would have.
But I don't think we prosecuted the war with the South Vietnamese properly.
I'm not really qualified to speak on that.
I think we could have done better, but I don't know.
Had I been in the position of power, exactly what I would have had to do differently.
Anything else?
No.
